The truly modest are modest even about their modesty. They do not know they are humble; they simply are. Such a one can cross the great water—the greatest danger—because they carry no weight of self-importance to sink them.

Modesty that finds expression. Perseverance brings good fortune. Modesty is not silence; it finds expression naturally, in the right way, at the right time. Not to draw attention, but to complete the situation. This expression, when persevered in, brings good fortune because it is true, not forced.

A superior person who is modest and toils. They carry things through. Good fortune. Modesty does not mean idleness. The modest person works, toils, completes. But they do not toil for recognition; they toil because the work needs doing. Their modesty makes their work effective because it is not about them. Good fortune follows.

Nothing that does not further modesty. In movement, this is natural. When you are truly modest, everything you do furthers the situation. Not because you are skillful, but because you are not in the way. Your actions flow from the situation itself, not from your agenda. This is natural movement, and it always furthers.

Not rich, use your neighbors. It furthers to attack and conquer. Nothing that does not further. Modesty does not mean poverty of spirit. If you lack resources, you use what is near—neighbors, friends, the given. Even attack and conquest, when necessary, can be done modestly—without arrogance, without cruelty. Nothing that is done in true modesty fails to further.

Modesty that expresses itself. It furthers to set armies marching and to attack cities. Even the harshest actions, when done in modesty—without personal pride, without cruelty—can be right. The line acknowledges that sometimes armies must march. But if they march modestly, they bring not destruction but resolution.

trigrams.description: Mountain under earth. The mountain's height is hidden, embraced by the earth. This is modesty: greatness that does not need to be seen, strength that rests within gentleness. The mountain does not disappear; it simply does not insist on its height.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The highest good is like water. Water benefits all things and does not contend. It stays in lowly places that others despise. Thus it is near the Tao.' Hexagram 15 is water's cousin—earth that embraces the mountain. Modesty is the quality of not needing to be above. It is the strength that rests below, the greatness that does not need to be seen. In this, it is near the Tao.

hexagrams.name: Enthusiasm (豫 - Yù)
hexagrams.heart: Thunder coming out of the earth. A shock, a stirring, a release of pent-up energy. Spring breaking through winter, joy breaking through sorrow. Enthusiasm is not manufactured; it erupts. It is the earth's own music, the rhythm that sets everything dancing. When it comes, you do not need to force it. You only need to let it move you.

ancient.rendering: Enthusiasm. It furthers one to install helpers and set armies marching.

hexagrams.judgment: Enthusiasm is the energy of heaven moving through earth. When it arises, it is time to act—not because you decide, but because you are moved. Install helpers: gather those who share your rhythm. Set armies marching: undertake the great tasks that require collective energy. But be careful: enthusiasm can become excess. The key is to be moved, not to be consumed. Let the thunder pass, and return to stillness.
hexagrams.image: Thunder bursts from the earth with a crash. The ancient kings made music to honor the worthy and offered it to the supreme deity. They introduced it to the ancestral temple. Thunder from the earth—sudden, powerful, musical. The ancient kings understood: enthusiasm must be channeled. They made music to honor the worthy, to give form to the formless energy. They offered it to the divine, to return it to its source. Enthusiasm, when honored and offered, becomes blessing. When ignored or indulged, it becomes chaos.
lines: Enthusiasm that expresses itself. Misfortune. Enthusiasm that is only expression, only release, without direction, without offering—this brings misfortune. It burns itself out and leaves nothing. The first line warns: do not just express; channel.

Enthusiasm that is like a rock. Not a whole day. Perseverance brings good fortune. The one who is rock-like, unmoved by enthusiasm, misses the gift. But if they do not stay rock-like for even a whole day—if they let themselves be touched—good fortune comes. Perseverance in openness, not in hardness.

Enthusiasm that looks upward creates remorse. There is delay, but no blame. Looking upward, yearning for what is beyond, creates remorse because you miss what is here. But if you see this and delay—pause, reflect—there is no blame. The yearning itself can become a path.

Enthusiasm as a source of doubt. Good fortune. When you doubt your own enthusiasm, you do not act rashly. This doubt is not weakness; it is the pause that lets you see clearly. Good fortune follows because you do not mistake excitement for truth.

Perseverance with chronic illness. Not dead. Enthusiasm can become chronic—a constant fever that wears you out. Perseverance in this state is not good, but you are not dead. The line offers hope: even chronic illness can be healed if you recognize it and return to stillness.

Dark enthusiasm. When enthusiasm is indulged without light, without awareness, it becomes dark. You lose yourself in it. But if you change afterward, there is no blame. The line does not condemn; it offers a way back.

trigrams.description: Earth below, thunder above. Thunder bursts from the earth—not from outside, but from within. Enthusiasm is the earth's own music, the vibration of life itself. When it comes, let it move you, but do not let it carry you away.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The five colors blind the eye. The five tones deafen the ear. The five flavors dull the taste. The chase and the hunt madden the mind.' Hexagram 16 warns of the same: enthusiasm, unchecked, becomes madness. But channeled, offered, returned to the source, it becomes music—the sound of the Tao moving through the world. The ancient kings made music not to excite but to honor. Let your enthusiasm be an offering, not an indulgence.

hexagrams.name: Following (随 - Suí)
hexagrams.heart: Thunder in the lake. Below, the deep stillness of water; above, the stirring of thunder. The lake follows the thunder's movement, rippling in response. Not by force, but by nature. Following is not submission; it is attunement. You follow not because you must, but because you recognize the right movement and join it.

ancient.rendering: Following has supreme success. Perseverance brings no blame.

hexagrams.judgment: To follow is not to lose yourself; it is to find yourself in rhythm with what is true. There are times when the highest wisdom is to join, not to lead. Supreme success comes when you follow the right leader, the right moment, the right way. Perseverance in this following brings no blame because you are not blindly obeying—you are consciously attuning. The lake does not lose itself by rippling; it expresses itself more fully. So too, in following, you become more yourself, not less.
hexagrams.image: Thunder in the lake. The noble one goes to his resting place at nightfall. He is restored. Thunder stirs the lake, but only briefly. Then the lake returns to stillness. The noble one learns from this: activity has its time, and rest has its time. At nightfall, he withdraws, rests, is restored. Following the natural rhythm of day and night, he does not exhaust himself. He follows the Tao, and the Tao restores him.
lines: The standard changes. Perseverance brings good fortune. To go out of the gate to fellowship brings success. Following does not mean rigidity. The standard changes as circumstances change. If you persevere in the old way when the new way is needed, you lose the path. Going out of the gate to fellowship—opening to others—brings success because you follow the moment, not the rule.

If you cling to the little boy, you lose the strong man. What you follow determines what you become. Cling to the small, and you lose the great. This line is a mirror: look at what you follow. Does it enlarge you or diminish you?

If you cling to the strong man, you lose the little boy. Following what is great, you may lose touch with simplicity, with the common, with the small joys. This is also a loss. The wise one follows both, at the right time, without clinging.

Following brings success. Perseverance brings misfortune. To go one's own way with sincerity brings clarity. There is a time to follow and a time to lead. If you persevere in following when you should lead, misfortune comes. The sincere person knows when to go their own way, and that going is itself a form of following—following the inner voice.

Sincere in the good. Good fortune. Following what is genuinely good, without pretense, without calculation—this brings good fortune because it aligns you with the source of all good. You are not following a person or a rule; you are following goodness itself.

He is bound, he is held fast. The king introduces him to the Western Mountain. Following reaches its peak: complete trust, complete attunement. The one who follows so completely is bound to the leader, held fast in the relationship. The king introduces him to the Western Mountain—the place of sacrifice, of highest honor. This is the fulfillment of following: not loss of self, but completion of self in relationship.

trigrams.description: Thunder below, lake above. The thunder stirs, and the lake responds—not by force, but by nature. This is following: the joyful, reflective response to the movement of life. The lake does not resist the thunder; it ripples. It does not lose itself; it expresses itself more fully.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'Yield and overcome; empty and become full; bend and become straight.' Hexagram 17 is the art of yielding, of following, of becoming full by emptying. The lake follows the thunder and becomes more fully lake. You follow the Tao and become more fully yourself. This is the paradox: in following, you lead. In yielding, you overcome. In emptying, you are filled.

hexagrams.name: Work on the Decayed (蛊 - Gǔ)
hexagrams.heart: Wind under the mountain. Below, the mountain, solid and still; above, the wind, moving and penetrating. But the wind is trapped, blowing against the mountain's base, eroding it slowly. This is decay—not sudden collapse, but the gradual wearing away of what was solid. And it is also work on the decay—the patient, persistent effort to set right what has been neglected. The mountain can be restored, but only if the wind's work is understood and redirected.

ancient.chinese: 蛊。元亨。利涉大川，先甲三日，後甲三日。
ancient.rendering: Work on what has been spoiled has supreme success. It furthers one to cross the great water. Three days before, three days after.

hexagrams.judgment: Everything decays. What was built crumbles, what was planted withers, what was established is neglected. This is not failure; it is the nature of time. But decay can be worked on. It can be healed, restored, renewed. Supreme success comes to those who take up this work. To cross the great water—the great difficulty—is possible if you prepare. Three days before, three days after: the work requires careful consideration of causes and effects, origins and consequences. You must understand how the decay happened to know how to undo it. And you must look ahead to see what the restoration will bring.
hexagrams.image: Wind below the mountain. The noble one stirs up the people and nourishes their character. Wind under the mountain: it blows against the base, eroding, weakening. But the same wind, redirected, can also clear away what is rotten and bring fresh air. The noble one looks at this image and learns: to work on decay, you must stir up the people—awaken them from complacency—and nourish their character—provide the conditions for new growth. Decay is not just physical; it is moral, spiritual, communal. The work is never only on things; it is always on people.
lines: Dealing with the decay caused by the father. The son takes over. No blame. Danger. In the end, good fortune. The decay you inherit—from your father, your predecessors, your past. You did not cause it, but you must deal with it. The son takes over. This is right, this is duty. There is danger—the decay may be deep, the work may be long—but in the end, good fortune comes to those who take up the work they did not choose.

Dealing with the decay caused by the mother. Not to be persevered in. Some decay is not yours to fix. The mother's decay—the intimate, the emotional, the deeply personal—may require not your intervention but your acceptance. To persevere in trying to fix it is to make it worse. Know when to let be.

Dealing with the decay caused by the father. There will be some remorse, but no great blame. Some decay you can address only partially. You will feel remorse for what you cannot fix, but if you do what you can, there is no great blame. The work is never perfect; done is enough.

Tolerating the decay caused by the father. To go forward brings humiliation. If you tolerate the decay, if you look away, if you let it continue—then going forward in any other matter brings humiliation because you have not done your fundamental work. First, address what is yours to address.

Dealing with the decay caused by the father. You will be praised. When you take up the work and do it well, you will be praised—not for your brilliance, but for your faithfulness. Praise is not the goal, but it is the natural recognition of work rightly done.

He does not serve kings and princes. He sets himself higher goals. The highest work on decay is not on the external world but on yourself. Some must withdraw from service, from the world's demands, to cultivate their own ground. This is not escape; it is the deepest work. Setting yourself higher goals—integrity, clarity, peace—you address the decay that underlies all others.

trigrams.description: Wind under mountain. The wind blows at the mountain's base, eroding it slowly. This is decay: the gradual wearing away of what was solid. But the same wind, if directed upward, can clear away debris and bring fresh air. Work on the decay is redirecting the wind—using the same forces that caused the problem to heal it.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The softest thing in the world rides over the hardest thing in the world.' Hexagram 18 is the soft wind that erodes the hard mountain—and the same soft wind that, when turned, can restore it. Decay is natural; so is renewal. The work is not to fight decay but to understand it, to redirect it, to let it teach you. The wise one does not despair over what is spoiled; they ask what the spoiling reveals about what was neglected, and they begin again, with new attention.

hexagrams.name: Approach (临 - Lín)
hexagrams.heart: Earth above, lake below. The lake mirrors the earth; the earth feels the lake's presence. Approach is the moment of drawing near—not with force, but with presence. The leader approaches the people, the lover approaches the beloved, the sage approaches the student. In approach, something passes between them, something that changes both.

ancient.chinese: 临。元亨利貞。至于八月有凶。
ancient.rendering: Approach has supreme success. Perseverance furthers. When the eighth month comes, there is misfortune.

hexagrams.judgment: To approach is to draw near with openness, with sincerity, with the intention of meeting. This brings supreme success because it opens channels that were closed. Perseverance in approaching—not forcing, but consistently showing up—furthers all things. But the eighth month warns: all approaches have their season. What is near will eventually become distant. The cycle continues. Do not cling to the approach; let it flow, and when the eighth month comes, accept the withdrawal. Misfortune comes only if you try to hold what is meant to recede.
hexagrams.image: Earth above the lake. The noble one is inexhaustible in teaching and unlimited in containing the people. Earth above the lake: the lake reflects the earth, and the earth rests on the lake's presence. The noble one learns from this: teaching is an approach, an inexhaustible drawing near to those who learn. And containing the people is an approach too—holding them without grasping, supporting without controlling. The noble one's heart is like the lake, reflecting all who approach, and like the earth, containing all who rest.
lines: Joint approach. Perseverance brings good fortune. To approach together, with others, in shared intention—this is powerful. Perseverance in this joint approach brings good fortune because you are not alone, and your combined presence is greater than any single one.

Joint approach. Good fortune. Everything furthers. Again, joint approach, but now it is complete. Everything furthers because the approach is full, mutual, unreserved. When two or more approach each other with full sincerity, nothing stands in their way.

Sweet approach. Nothing that furthers. If you are already aware, you can avoid mistakes. Sweet approach—flattering, ingratiating, trying to win favor—does not further. It is not true approach; it is manipulation. If you are aware of this, you can avoid the mistake. Approach must be sincere, not sweet.

Complete approach. No blame. To approach completely, holding nothing back, risking everything—this is rare and often blamed by the cautious. But the line says: no blame. Complete approach, when it is called for, is the only right response. Hold nothing back.

Wise approach. This is right for a great ruler. Good fortune. To approach with wisdom—seeing clearly what is needed, what is possible, what is timely—this is the approach of the great ruler. It brings good fortune because it is not blind; it sees and yet still draws near.

Great approach. Good fortune. No blame. The ultimate approach: great in scale, great in intention, great in effect. Not because of any special quality, but because the approach itself has become a way of being. This one approaches everything—the world, others, themselves—with the same openness. Good fortune, no blame.

trigrams.description: Lake below, earth above. The lake reflects the earth, and the earth receives the lake's gift of reflection. This is approach: the mutual drawing near of what reflects and what is reflected. In approach, you see yourself in the other, and the other sees themselves in you. This seeing is the beginning of all healing.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The sage has no mind of his own; he takes the mind of the people as his mind.' Hexagram 19 is the sage's approach: not imposing, but reflecting; not controlling, but containing. The lake does not try to be the earth; it reflects it. The earth does not try to be the lake; it receives its reflection. In their mutual approach, each becomes more fully itself. The wise one approaches others the same way: not to change them, but to let them see themselves in the clear water of sincere presence.

hexagrams.name: Contemplation (观 - Guān)
hexagrams.heart: Wind moving over the earth. Everywhere, unseen, the wind touches everything. It cannot be seen, only felt. Contemplation is like this: not staring, not analyzing, but a quiet, pervasive awareness that takes in everything without grasping anything. You stand on the earth, and the wind moves over you. You see without looking, understand without thinking, are present without effort.

ancient.rendering: Contemplation. The ablution is made, but not the offering. Full of trust, they look up.

hexagrams.judgment: The ablution is made, but not the offering—the purification is complete, but the ritual is not yet performed. In that pause, there is pure contemplation. Full of trust, they look up—not asking, not demanding, just receiving. Contemplation is this sacred pause: after preparation, before action, you simply see. In that seeing, you understand what is needed, what is true, what is next. The offering will come, but first, contemplation. Do not rush to act. First, see.
hexagrams.image: Wind moving over the earth. The ancient kings visited the regions and observed the people. They established teaching. Wind over the earth: it goes everywhere, touches everything, but leaves no trace. The ancient kings, like wind, visited all regions, observed all people, not to control but to understand. From this understanding, they established teaching that fit each place, each people. Contemplation is the foundation of all wise action. First see, then act.
lines: Contemplation like a youth. No blame for a common person, but a superior person is humiliated. The youth sees only the surface, only what is obvious. For a common person, this is no blame—they have not learned to see deeper. But for the superior person, this shallow seeing is humiliation. You are called to see more deeply.

Contemplation through the crack of the door. Furthering for the perseverance of a woman. Through a crack, you see only a sliver. This is partial, limited, but for one who cannot go out—a woman in traditional confines—this limited seeing is enough. It furthers her perseverance. The line does not judge; it describes. Know the limits of your contemplation, and work within them.

Contemplation of one's own life. Determines whether to advance or retreat. This is the heart of contemplation: looking at your own life, your own path, your own choices. From this seeing, you know whether to advance or retreat. Not from external advice, not from rules, but from clear seeing of what is. This is the foundation of wisdom.

Contemplation of the light of the kingdom. It furthers to be a guest of the king. When you see beyond yourself to the larger whole—the kingdom, the community, the world—you become fit to serve. The king welcomes you as a guest because your seeing is not self-serving. You see what is needed, and you can help provide it.

Contemplation of one's own life. The superior person is without blame. Again, contemplation of one's own life, now at a deeper level. The superior person, seeing clearly, acts without blame because action flows from seeing. Not from impulse, not from habit, but from clear awareness.

Contemplation of one's own life. The superior person is without blame. The final line repeats the fifth, emphasizing that this is the culmination: the one who sees clearly, acts without blame. The cycle completes: from youth's surface, through the crack, to self, to the kingdom, back to self—and now, at the peak, simply seeing, simply being, without blame.

trigrams.description: Earth below, wind above. Wind moves over the earth, touching everything, leaving nothing untouched. This is contemplation: a gentle, pervasive awareness that takes in all without grasping any. The earth receives the wind; you receive the world. In this receiving, you understand.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'Without going out the door, know the world. Without looking out the window, see the Tao.' Hexagram 20 is this knowing without going, this seeing without looking. Contemplation is not the effort to understand; it is the openness that allows understanding to come. The wind does not try to know the earth; it simply moves over it, and in moving, learns every contour. You do not need to strive to see. Just be present, and the world will show itself to you.

hexagrams.name: Biting Through (噬嗑 - Shì Kè)
hexagrams.heart: Thunder and lightning. The flash that illuminates, the shock that breaks. Between the jaws, something stuck—the clamp that prevents closing. Biting through is the force that removes obstacles, that chews through what blocks the way. Not gentle, not patient—but sometimes necessary. The jaws must close for nourishment to happen. If something blocks them, bite through.

ancient.rendering: Biting Through succeeds. It is favorable to use legal proceedings.

hexagrams.judgment: There are times when the only way forward is to bite through the obstacle. Not with anger, not with cruelty—but with the clear, decisive force of a jaw closing on what blocks nourishment. This is the energy of legal proceedings, of judgment, of setting things right by force when gentleness has failed. Success comes not from the violence, but from the clearing. After the obstacle is removed, the jaws can close in peace. Use this force only when necessary, and only to restore the natural flow.
hexagrams.image: Thunder and lightning. The ancient kings made their laws clear and promulgated punishments. Thunder and lightning together—the flash that reveals and the shock that enforces. The ancient kings understood: laws must be clear so all can see, and punishments must be known so all can choose. Biting through is not about cruelty; it is about clarity. When the law is clear, people can avoid the bite. When punishment is just, the obstacle is removed and the whole benefits.
lines: His feet are in the stocks, so that his toes disappear. No blame. The smallest obstacle, the first offense—the stocks confine the toes, not the whole body. The punishment fits the crime. No blame because the correction is minimal, a warning, not a destruction.

Bites through soft meat, and his nose disappears. No blame. The obstacle is soft, easy to bite—but in the eagerness, he loses his nose, his sensitivity. No blame because the obstacle was removed, but a reminder: even in easy victories, something is lost. Bite through, but do not lose yourself.

Bites on old dried meat, and strikes something poisonous. Slight humiliation. No blame. Old meat, tough and poisoned—the obstacle is more than expected. He bites and is poisoned, humiliated. But the line says no blame: he did what was necessary, and the poison is not his fault. Endure the humiliation; the obstacle will still yield.

Bites on dried gristly meat. Receives metal arrows. It furthers to persevere in the face of difficulty. Good fortune. The toughest obstacle—gristle, bone, the hardest to chew. But he receives metal arrows, tools that help. Perseverance in this difficulty brings good fortune. The arrows are the helpers, the resources that come when the task is great. Use them.

Bites on dried lean meat. Receives yellow gold. Perseverance brings danger. No blame. Lean meat, less tough, but still requiring bite. He receives yellow gold—value, reward. But the line warns: perseverance in this mode brings danger. Do not make biting through a habit. After the obstacle, return to gentleness. No blame if you know when to stop.

His neck is in the wooden cangue, so that his ears disappear. Misfortune. The final line: the worst obstacle, the greatest punishment. The cangue confines the neck, blocks the ears. Misfortune because the obstacle was not addressed early, and now it consumes the whole. Learn from this: bite through the small things before they become large.

trigrams.description: Thunder below, lightning above. The flash reveals what is stuck; the shock breaks it apart. Together, they bite through any obstacle. This is the power of clarity joined with movement: first see, then act.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'If you want to shrink something, you must first expand it. If you want to weaken something, you must first strengthen it.' Hexagram 21 is the moment of contraction after expansion, of weakening after strengthening. The obstacle grew until it blocked the way. Now it must be bitten through. The wise one does not let obstacles grow that large. They address the small before it becomes large, the easy before it becomes hard.

hexagrams.name: Grace (贲 - Bì)
hexagrams.heart: Fire at the foot of the mountain. The mountain, solid and still, is lit by fire—not consumed, but illuminated. Grace is this: the light that reveals without burning, the beauty that adorns without covering. A single flower in a simple vase, a well-placed word in silence. Grace adds nothing essential, yet without it, the essential remains unseen.

ancient.rendering: Grace succeeds. In small matters, it furthers one to undertake something.

hexagrams.judgment: Grace is not necessary, but it is not trivial. It is the finishing touch, the light that reveals, the beauty that honors. In great matters, grace alone is not enough—substance must come first. But in small matters, it furthers to undertake grace. A kind word, a thoughtful gesture, a beautiful object—these make life human. Success comes not from the grace itself, but from what grace makes visible. Let your grace reveal what is real, not cover what is absent.
hexagrams.image: Fire at the foot of the mountain. The noble one sheds light on the many proceedings of government, but does not dare to decide court cases. Fire at the mountain's base illuminates the lower slopes but cannot reach the peak. The noble one learns: grace can illuminate processes, can make things clear and beautiful, but it cannot decide what is just. For that, something more is needed. Use grace to shed light, but do not rely on it for judgment.
lines: He lends grace to his toes, leaves the carriage, and walks. To grace the smallest part, the toes, and then to leave the carriage—the luxury—and walk humbly. This is grace that knows its place. It adorns but does not cling. Good fortune follows such lightness.

He lends grace to his beard. The beard is already there; grace simply trims it, shapes it. This is grace that works with what is, not against it. No great transformation, just a little attention. Good fortune in the small.

Graceful and moist. Perseverance brings good fortune. Moisture softens, makes pliable. Grace that moistens—that softens the hard edges—brings good fortune if persevered in. Not the flashy grace, but the steady, softening presence.

Grace or simplicity? A white horse comes, not as a robber but as a suitor. The question: should you add grace or remain simple? The answer comes as a white horse—purity, simplicity itself—but it comes as a suitor, seeking union. Sometimes the greatest grace is no grace at all. The simplicity itself becomes the ornament.

Grace in the hills and gardens. The roll of silk is meager and small. Humiliation, but in the end, good fortune. Grace in retreat—in hills and gardens, away from the world—is humble, meager. It seems like humiliation, lacking the world's splendor. But in the end, this simple grace brings good fortune because it is real, not performed.

Simple grace. No blame. The final line returns to the beginning: simple grace, unadorned, unpretentious. After all the ornament, the only grace that lasts is the one that adds nothing, that simply lets what is be seen. No blame.

trigrams.description: Fire below, mountain above. The fire illuminates the mountain's base, revealing its beauty without reaching its peak. This is grace: light that reveals form without consuming it, beauty that honors substance without replacing it.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The five colors blind the eye. The five tones deafen the ear.' Hexagram 22 warns: grace can become excess, ornament can become blindness. But true grace is not excess; it is the light that lets you see what is already there. The wise one adorns just enough to reveal, never enough to conceal.

hexagrams.name: Splitting Apart (剥 - Bō)
hexagrams.heart: Mountain resting on earth. But the earth is giving way, eroding, sliding. The mountain, once secure, now splits apart. Not by violence from outside, but by gradual weakening from within. Splitting apart is the slow decay of what seemed solid—a relationship, a reputation, a self. It happens one small betrayal at a time, one unnoticed crack. By the time you see it, it is almost too late.

ancient.rendering: Splitting Apart. It does not further one to undertake anything.

hexagrams.judgment: When things are splitting apart, when the ground is eroding under you, it does not further to undertake anything new. Any action now only accelerates the decay. The only wisdom is to wait, to preserve what can be preserved, to let the decay complete itself. This is not passive resignation; it is recognition that some processes must finish before new ones can begin. The mountain will fall, but from its rubble, new earth will form. Wait.
hexagrams.image: The mountain rests on the earth. The noble one ensures abundance for those below, and peace for their dwelling. The mountain rests on earth, but when the earth erodes, the mountain falls. The noble one looks at this image and learns: ensure abundance for those below—the foundation, the common people, the ordinary ones. Give them peace in their dwelling. When the base is secure, the mountain stands. Splitting apart happens from neglect of the foundation. Attend to the foundation, and the mountain holds.
lines: The leg of the bed is split. Those who persevere are destroyed. Misfortune. The first crack, in the leg of the bed—the place of rest. It seems small, but if you persevere in ignoring it, you are destroyed. The bed will collapse. Misfortune comes not from the crack, but from the refusal to see it.

The bed is split at the edge. Those who persevere are destroyed. Misfortune. The crack spreads to the edge. Still ignorable, still small—but not for long. The warning repeats: do not persevere in denial. Act now, or be destroyed.

Splits apart with them. No blame. The decay is shared, collective. You are not alone in the splitting. There is no blame because it is not your doing alone. But neither is there safety. The split continues.

The bed is split down to the skin. Misfortune. Now the crack reaches the body, the self. Misfortune because it can no longer be ignored. The decay is now you. But even here, there is a seed: when it reaches you, you must finally respond.

A shoal of fish. Favor comes through the court ladies. Everything acts to their advantage. In the midst of splitting, a shoal of fish—many small things moving together. Favor comes through the most unlikely channels—the court ladies, the overlooked ones. Suddenly, everything acts to your advantage. The decay has created space for the new.

There is a large fruit still uneaten. The noble one acquires a carriage. The common people split their huts. The large fruit remains, untouched by decay. The noble one acquires a carriage—a way to move, to carry what matters. The common people lose their huts, but the noble one has what they need to start again. In the final splitting, the seed of the new is preserved.

trigrams.description: Earth below, mountain above. The mountain rests on earth, but the earth erodes. This is splitting apart: the foundation crumbling under the weight of what it supports. When the base fails, the peak falls. Attend to the foundation.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'What is firmly established cannot be uprooted. What is firmly embraced cannot slip away.' Hexagram 23 shows what happens when nothing is firmly established, when the embrace was never true. Splitting apart is the price of neglect. But the large fruit remains—the seed of what was real. The wise one preserves that fruit, and from it, new growth springs.

hexagrams.name: Return (复 - Fù)
hexagrams.heart: Thunder within the earth. After the longest night, the faintest stirring. After the deepest winter, the first green shoot. Return is not arrival; it is the turn toward arrival. The solstice, when darkness peaks and light begins its slow return. Not yet spring, but the turn toward spring. Not yet healed, but the turn toward healing. This is the most hopeful of hexagrams: nothing is final. Everything returns.

ancient.chinese: 复。亨。出入无疾，朋來无咎。反復其道，七日來復，利有攸往。
ancient.rendering: Return succeeds. Going out and coming in without hurt. Friends come without blame. The way moves in cycles. After seven days, return comes. It furthers one to undertake something.

hexagrams.judgment: After splitting apart, return. After decay, renewal. This is the law of the Tao: everything returns. Going out and coming in without hurt—the cycle is natural, not forced. Friends come without blame—in the time of return, you are not alone. After seven days—after a complete cycle—return comes. Now it furthers to undertake something. The time of waiting is over. The turn has come. Act, but gently. The return is just beginning; do not demand the full harvest yet.
hexagrams.image: Thunder within the earth. The ancient kings closed the passes on the winter solstice. Merchants did not travel. The rulers did not tour. Thunder within the earth—the stirring is there, but still hidden. The ancient kings honored this by closing the passes, by ceasing activity. They understood: at the moment of return, do not rush out. Let the stirring grow in secret. Rest, wait, prepare. The time for action will come, but not yet. First, honor the turn.
lines: Return from a short distance. No need for regret. Great good fortune. You have not wandered far. The return is easy, quick. No need for regret—you caught yourself early. This is great good fortune because the cost of return is small. Learn from this: return as soon as you notice the wandering.

Quiet return. Good fortune. Not dramatic, not public—just a quiet turning back, a silent reorientation. No one notices, but you feel it. This is good fortune because it is deep, because it comes from within, not from pressure without.

Repeated return. Danger. No blame. You return, then wander again, return again. This repeated cycling is dangerous—it wears you out. But the line says no blame because you keep returning. Even the repeated return is better than no return. Persist, and eventually the wandering will lessen.

Walking in the midst of others, you return alone. This return is solitary. You are surrounded by those still going the wrong way, but you turn. Alone, you walk back. This takes courage. There is no blame—only the quiet strength of one who follows their own knowing.

Noble-hearted return. No regret. You return not because you wandered, but because you see more deeply. This return is an advance, a deepening. Noble-hearted, you turn toward what is more real. No regret—only gratitude.

Missing the return. Misfortune. There is misfortune in leading armies. In the end, a great defeat. If you miss the moment of return, if you stay on the wrong path too long, the consequence is severe. Like leading armies when you should retreat—great defeat. The line warns: do not miss the return. The turn is always there, but you must take it.

trigrams.description: Thunder within the earth. The stirring is there, but hidden—the first movement of spring under winter's ground. Return is this hidden stirring, the promise of renewal before any sign appears. Trust it. It is real.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'Returning is the movement of the Tao.' Hexagram 24 is that movement made visible. After every departure, a return. After every winter, a spring. After every death, a rebirth. The wise one does not despair at the going, because they trust the returning. The way moves in cycles, and you are part of that movement. Return now, and let the cycle complete.

hexagrams.name: Innocence (无妄 - Wú Wàng)
hexagrams.heart: Thunder under heaven. The shock of the real, the unexpected, the undeserved. Innocence is not naivete; it is the quality of acting without expectation, without calculation, without hidden motive. Thunder under heaven—it comes when it comes, strikes what it strikes, asks nothing in return. This is the innocence of nature: it simply does what it does, and we call it good or bad, but it is just itself.

ancient.chinese: 无妄。元亨利貞。其匪正有眚，不利有攸往。
ancient.rendering: Innocence. Supreme success, perseverance furthers. If one is not as he should be, he has misfortune. It does not further to undertake anything.

hexagrams.judgment: Supreme success comes to those who act without artifice, without scheme, without hidden agenda. Not because the world rewards innocence, but because innocent action is aligned with the Tao. It does not force, does not manipulate, does not regret. But if you are not as you should be—if you pretend innocence while hiding intent—then misfortune follows. In such a state, it does not further to undertake anything. First, become real.
hexagrams.image: Thunder under heaven. The ancient kings enriched their virtue in harmony with the seasons. Thunder under heaven: the sound rolls everywhere, touching all equally. The ancient kings learned from this: enrich your virtue in harmony with the seasons—not forcing, not rushing, but letting virtue grow as naturally as thunder comes in its time. Innocence is this natural growth, unforced, uncalculated, simply being what you are when the time is right.
lines: Innocent action brings good fortune. Acting without expectation, without attachment to outcome—this is innocent. Good fortune follows because you are not tied to results. You act, and let go. The universe responds in kind.

If you do not count on the harvest while plowing, or on the cleared field while cultivating, then it furthers to undertake something. This is the heart of innocence: plow without thinking of harvest, cultivate without thinking of the cleared field. Do the work because it is the work, not because of what it will bring. Then it furthers to undertake anything.

Innocence that leads to misfortune. Someone ties up the cow. The traveler's gain is the native's loss. Even innocent action can lead to misfortune, through no fault of your own. Someone ties up the cow—your resource, your support. The traveler gains what the native loses. This is the unpredictability of innocence. You act rightly, and still lose. The line does not blame; it observes. Even in loss, remain innocent.

He who can persevere in innocence remains without blame. When innocence is tested, when misfortune comes, if you can persevere—remain innocent, not becoming cynical or calculating—you remain without blame. The test proves the innocence, not its failure.

Do not use medicine for an illness incurred through no fault of your own. It will heal of itself. Some things come to you innocently—illness, trouble, loss. Do not rush to fix them with artificial means. If you are innocent, if you did not cause them, they will heal of themselves. This is trust in the Tao's own rhythm.

Innocent action brings misfortune. Nothing furthers. Sometimes, even innocence meets misfortune. Nothing furthers in that moment. The line does not explain or justify; it simply states. Some things are beyond help. In such times, remain innocent. That is all you can do.

trigrams.description: Thunder under heaven. The sound rolls across the sky, touching all equally, asking nothing. This is innocence: action that is simply itself, without calculation, without expectation. Heaven receives it, and the world is shaken—not by force, but by truth.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The sage has no mind of his own. He takes the mind of the people as his mind.' Hexagram 25 is the sage's mind: innocent, open, responsive. Not empty of intent, but empty of agenda. Like thunder, it speaks when it speaks, and the world listens. The wise one acts without acting, and nothing is left undone.

hexagrams.name: Great Taming (大畜 - Dà Chù)
hexagrams.heart: Mountain above heaven. The mountain, vast and still, rests on the creative power below. It does not crush; it contains. This is great taming: not the small, patient influence of wind on sky, but the massive, quiet holding of mountain over heaven. The creative power is there, fully present, but it is held, channeled, given time to gather. Great taming is the discipline that allows power to accumulate until it is ready to move mountains itself.

ancient.chinese: 大畜。利貞。不家食吉。利涉大川。
ancient.rendering: Great Taming. Perseverance furthers. Not eating at home brings good fortune. It furthers one to cross the great water.

hexagrams.judgment: There is a time to gather, to hold, to let power accumulate. This is great taming. Not suppression, but containment. The mountain does not fight heaven; it simply rests on it, giving it time to gather strength. Perseverance in this gathering furthers. Not eating at home—going out, engaging with the world—brings good fortune because the power you have gathered is now ready to be used. Crossing the great water, the great difficulty, is now possible because you did not rush. You waited until you were ready.
hexagrams.image: Mountain above heaven. The noble one learns widely of past words and deeds, and thus accumulates virtue. Mountain above heaven: the highest rests on the most powerful. The noble one looks at this image and learns: to accumulate virtue, learn widely from the past. Not just your own experience, but the words and deeds of those who came before. Their gathered wisdom becomes the mountain that rests on your heaven, channeling your power, giving it direction. Great taming is this accumulation of wisdom over time.
lines: Danger is at hand. It furthers to stop. When the first sign of danger appears, stop. Not out of fear, but out of wisdom. The great taming begins with knowing when not to act. Stop now, and you preserve your power for when it is needed.

The axle is removed from the wagon. The wagon cannot move. This is not failure; it is the taming itself. The axle is removed so that you cannot rush forward. You are forced to wait, to gather. There is no blame in this stillness. It is preparation.

A good horse that follows. It furthers to be aware of danger and to persevere. Now movement is possible—a good horse, strong and willing. But the warning remains: be aware of danger, and persevere in the awareness. The horse can run, but you must guide it. Great taming continues even in movement.

The headboard of a young bull. Great good fortune. The bull is strong, but its headboard—the restraint—keeps it from harming. This is the paradox of great taming: the restraint itself is what allows the power to grow safely. Great good fortune comes from this wise containment.

The tusk of a gelded boar. Good fortune. The boar's tusk is its weapon. Gelded, the boar is still strong, but its aggression is tempered. The tusk remains, but it is no longer a danger. This is great taming: power that has been transformed, not removed. The essence remains; the harm is gone.

What is the way of heaven? It prospers. The culmination: after all the taming, the gathering, the restraint—now heaven's way simply prospers. The power that was held is now released, not by force, but by nature. It flows, it gives, it completes. This is the fruit of great taming.

trigrams.description: Heaven below, mountain above. The mountain rests on heaven, containing it, channeling it. This is great taming: the creative power held in stillness, allowed to gather until it is ready to move mountains itself. The restraint is not weakness; it is the condition of true strength.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'To know the masculine and keep to the feminine is to be the valley of the world.' Hexagram 26 is the valley that holds the mountain. The creative power is masculine, active, strong. The great taming keeps to the feminine—still, receptive, containing—and thus becomes the valley that can hold even heaven. From this holding, true power is born.

hexagrams.name: Corners of the Mouth (颐 - Yí)
hexagrams.heart: Thunder under the mountain. Below, the stirring of life; above, the stillness that receives it. The mouth opens and closes, takes in nourishment, gives out words. This is the simplest and most profound of acts: providing for life. Corners of the Mouth is about nourishment—physical, mental, spiritual. What you take in, what you give out, and the quiet rhythm between them.

ancient.rendering: Corners of the Mouth. Perseverance brings good fortune. Contemplate the corners of the mouth, and seek your own nourishment.

hexagrams.judgment: Good fortune comes to those who attend to nourishment. Not just food, but everything that enters and leaves the self. Contemplate the corners of the mouth—what you take in, what you give out, and the rhythm between them. Seek your own nourishment, not as an act of selfishness, but as recognition that you cannot give what you do not have. Perseverance in this attention brings good fortune because you become a reliable channel for life.
hexagrams.image: Thunder under the mountain. The noble one is careful in his words and moderate in eating and drinking. Thunder under the mountain: the stirring of life beneath stillness. The noble one learns: be careful in words—what leaves the mouth—and moderate in eating and drinking—what enters. This double attention keeps the channel clear. Nourishment flows both ways when you attend to both.
lines: You let your magic tortoise go, and look at me with the corners of your mouth hanging down. Misfortune. The magic tortoise is your own inner resource, your capacity for self-nourishment. You let it go, and now you look to others with envy, with neediness. Misfortune follows because you have abandoned your own source.

Turning to the top for nourishment. Going against what is constant. Perseverance brings misfortune. To seek nourishment from those above, from those who should not be your source—this is against the constant order. Persevering in this brings misfortune. Nourishment flows downward, not upward.

Turning away from nourishment. Perseverance brings danger. Misfortune for ten years. Nothing good. To refuse nourishment altogether, to turn away from what sustains you—this brings danger. Ten years—a complete cycle—without nourishment, nothing good can come. The line is stark: do not refuse what life offers.

Turning to the source for nourishment. Good fortune. With keen eyes like a tiger's, with insatiable longing. No blame. Finally, turning to the right source—the source itself, not a proxy. The desire is keen, like a tiger's hunger, insatiable. This longing is not greed; it is life seeking its own. No blame follows such true seeking.

Turning away from what is constant. Perseverance brings good fortune. Not to cross the great water. Even when you turn from the constant, if you persevere in awareness, good fortune can come. But do not cross the great water—do not undertake great things—while still unsteady. First, return to nourishment.

The source of nourishment. Awareness of danger brings good fortune. It furthers to cross the great water. At last, you have found the source itself, and you are aware of the danger of losing it. This awareness itself is protection. Now it furthers to cross the great water—to undertake the great thing. You are nourished, and you know it.

trigrams.description: Thunder under mountain. The stirring of life beneath stillness. The mouth opens (thunder) and closes (mountain), taking in and giving out. This is the rhythm of nourishment: the movement that receives and the stillness that processes. Both are necessary.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The sage does not accumulate. The more he helps others, the more he possesses. The more he gives to others, the more he gains.' Hexagram 27 is the foundation of this paradox: you cannot give what you have not received. Nourishment is the source of all giving. Attend to your own corners of the mouth, and you will have something to offer. Neglect them, and you become a beggar looking at others with envy.

hexagrams.name: Preponderance of the Great (大過 - Dà Guò)
hexagrams.heart: The ridgepole sags. The central beam, meant to bear the weight, bends under the strain. The house is sound, the ends are firm—but the middle gives way. This is preponderance of the great: too much weight in the center, too little support at the edges. Extraordinary times call for extraordinary measures. The ridgepole must be replaced, or the house will fall.

ancient.rendering: Preponderance of the Great. The ridgepole sags. It furthers one to undertake something. Success.

hexagrams.judgment: When the center cannot hold, when the weight is too great, you must act. The ridgepole sags—this is the sign. It furthers to undertake something. Not cautious waiting, not gentle taming, but decisive action. Success comes not from avoiding the crisis, but from meeting it with equal weight. In times of great preponderance, ordinary rules do not apply. You must do what the moment demands, even if it seems excessive. The house can be saved, but only if you act now.
hexagrams.image: The lake rises above the trees. The noble one stands alone and is undaunted. The lake rises above the trees—water over wood, a preponderance of the yielding over the firm. In such times, the noble one stands alone. Not because they are isolated, but because they are undaunted by the extraordinary. They do not seek company in crisis; they seek truth. Alone, they act, and the world follows or does not. They are undaunted either way.
lines: To spread white rushes underneath. No blame. When the weight is great, prepare the ground. Spread rushes—soft, yielding—to cushion the fall. This is not weakness; it is wisdom. In extraordinary times, even small preparations matter. No blame.

A withered poplar puts forth a shoot. An old man takes a young wife. Everything furthers. The withered springs new life. The old man, through union with the young, finds renewal. This is the preponderance of the great manifesting as new growth from decay. Everything furthers because the extraordinary situation calls forth extraordinary life.

The ridgepole sags. Misfortune. The sagging is visible, the crisis present. Misfortune because it cannot be ignored. But the line does not end there. It is a fact, not a verdict. The sagging is; now you must respond.

The ridgepole is braced. Good fortune. If there is ulterior motive, it is humiliating. The brace is applied—the crisis is met. Good fortune follows the right action. But if you act with hidden motive, with self-interest disguised as help, humiliation follows. The brace must be pure.

A withered poplar puts forth flowers. An old woman takes a young husband. No blame. No praise. Flowers on a withered poplar—brief, fragile, beautiful, but not lasting. An old woman with a young husband—possible, but not the usual course. No blame, no praise. The extraordinary simply is. Do not judge it; just see it.

Disaster. Wading through water so deep it covers the head. Misfortune. No blame. The final line: disaster, water over the head, drowning. Misfortune, yes. But the line says no blame. Because sometimes the extraordinary overwhelms, and it is not your fault. You waded as far as you could. The water covered you. No blame.

trigrams.description: Wind below, lake above. The wind stirs the lake, but the lake rises above the trees—a preponderance of water over wood, of yielding over firm. This is extraordinary times: the normal order is inverted, and what is usually above is now below. In such times, be ready for anything.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The heavy is the root of the light. The still is the master of the restless.' Hexagram 28 is the loss of this root, this mastery. The ridgepole sags because the weight is too great, the center too heavy. The wise one, in such times, becomes the root, the still point. They stand alone and undaunted, and in their stillness, the house finds a new center.

hexagrams.name: The Abysmal (坎 - Kǎn)
hexagrams.heart: Water over water. Deep calls to deep. The abyss is not one, but two—danger upon danger, depth within depth. This is the nature of the abysmal: you fall, and then you fall again. You think you have reached bottom, and the bottom opens. There is no solid ground, only water, only the endless falling. And yet, water does not fear the abyss. It simply fills it.

ancient.rendering: The Abysmal. If you are sincere, your heart succeeds. Action brings honor.

hexagrams.judgment: The abyss is real. Danger upon danger, depth within depth. But if you are sincere—if your heart is true, if you do not pretend—then your heart succeeds even in the depths. Not by escaping, but by being fully present. Action in the abyss brings honor, not because you conquer it, but because you meet it without flinching. Water does not fight the abyss; it fills it. You do not need to escape; you need to be fully where you are. In that fullness, the abyss becomes your ground.
hexagrams.image: Water flows and never fills. The noble one walks in lasting virtue and practices the business of teaching. Water flows endlessly, never filling, never emptying. It simply continues. The noble one learns from this: walk in lasting virtue—not dramatic virtue, but steady, continuous, like water. Practice the business of teaching—pass on what you know, not as a flood, but as a constant stream. In the abyss, this steady flow is the only way. You cannot fill it; you can only move through it.
lines: In the abyss, you fall into a pit. Misfortune. The first step: you fall, and then fall again. The double abyss. Misfortune because it seems endless. But the line only observes; it does not despair. The fall is real; now you are in the pit.

In the abyss, you strive for small things. Only reaching the rim brings safety. In the depths, do not strive for great things. Small things—a handhold, a breath, a moment of clarity. Reach for the rim, not the sky. Small gains bring safety.

Coming and going, abyss upon abyss. In danger like this, pause, and do not act. If you act, you will only sink deeper. The abyss upon abyss requires stillness, not action. Pause. Let the waters settle. Then, perhaps, a way will appear.

A jug of wine, a bowl of rice, earthen vessels simply handed through the window. There is certainly no blame in this. In the abyss, simple offerings, humble gifts—a jug of wine, a bowl of rice—passed through the smallest opening. This is enough. No blame because you give what you can, and it is received. Connection, even in the depths, sustains.

The abyss is not filled to overflowing; it is filled only to the rim. No blame. Do not try to fill the abyss. You cannot. Fill only to the rim—enough for now, enough to keep going. No blame because you accept the limit. The abyss remains, but you are not drowned.

Bound with cords and ropes, shut in a prison, for three years you do not find the way. Misfortune. The deepest abyss: bound, imprisoned, cut off. For three years—a complete cycle—you do not find the way. Misfortune. The line is stark, without comfort. Some abysses hold you that long. But even here, the water flows. Even here, you are still in motion, still alive. The way may not appear for three years, but it will appear.

trigrams.description: Water over water. Abyss upon abyss. There is no solid ground, only depth calling to depth. This is the nature of danger: it compounds, it deepens. But water does not resist; it flows. In the abyss, become water. Flow, and you will find a way.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The supreme good is like water. It benefits all things and does not contend. It stays in lowly places that others despise. Thus it is near the Tao.' Hexagram 29 is the lowliest place of all—the abyss itself. And water is there, already there, because water always seeks the lowest. The abyss is water's home. When you fall into the abyss, you are not falling away from the Tao; you are falling into it. Be sincere, let your heart succeed, and the water will carry you.

hexagrams.name: The Clinging (离 - Lí)
hexagrams.heart: Fire over fire. Brightness upon brightness. Flame clings to its fuel, yet is never the fuel. It depends, yet it transforms. This is the nature of the clinging: to be dependent and yet independent, to receive and yet give. Fire cannot exist without something to burn, yet in burning, it gives light and warmth. Clinging is not weakness; it is the recognition that all things exist in relationship. Even the sun clings to the sky.

ancient.rendering: The Clinging. Perseverance furthers. Success. Nourish the cow, and good fortune follows.

hexagrams.judgment: To cling is not to grasp; it is to depend rightly, to relate truly. Fire clings to its fuel, but does not possess it. You cling to what sustains you—people, places, practices—but if you try to possess them, the fire goes out. Perseverance in right relationship furthers. Nourish the cow—the gentle, the yielding, the receptive—and good fortune follows. Not because you control, but because you tend. Clinging, rightly done, is the source of all light.
hexagrams.image: Brightness rising twice. The great person continues the light and illuminates the four quarters. Brightness twice—fire over fire, light multiplied. The great person looks at this image and learns: continue the light. Not your own light only, but the light of those who came before, the light of tradition, of teaching, of example. Continue it, and illuminate the four quarters. Clinging is this continuation: you hold what was given, add your own flame, and pass it on.
lines: The steps are wrong. But respect can overcome blame. The first step falters, the foot slips. But if you approach with respect—respect for the fire, for what you cling to—the blame can be overcome. Respectful attention corrects many errors.

Yellow light. Supreme good fortune. Yellow is the color of earth, of center, of balance. Light that is yellow—warm, steady, not blinding—this is supreme good fortune. Clinging that is balanced, that does not consume or exhaust, that simply illuminates. This is the light to seek.

Light of the setting sun. If you do not beat the pot and sing, you will sigh in old age. Misfortune. The light fades, as all light fades. If you do not celebrate what remains—beat the pot and sing—you will spend your last days in regret. Clinging accepts the fading and still finds joy. If you cannot, misfortune follows.

Its coming is sudden. It flames up, dies down, is discarded. The sudden blaze—intense, brief, then ash. This is not the clinging that lasts. Do not cling to what flames up suddenly; it will leave you as quickly as it came.

Tears in floods, sighing and lamenting. Good fortune. The depth of feeling, the flood of tears, the honest grief—this is also clinging. To love is to risk loss, and to loss is to weep. The line says good fortune because the tears are real, the grief is true. This honest clinging, even in sorrow, brings its own light.

The king uses him to march forth and punish. He captures the leader and his followers. No wound. Good fortune. At the peak, the clinging one is used for righteous action. He captures the leader and the followers—completes the task—and emerges unwounded. Good fortune because he clung to what was right and let it guide him. The fire did not burn him; it lit his way.

trigrams.description: Fire over fire. Brightness upon brightness. Flame depends on fuel, yet transforms it. This is clinging: the recognition that all existence is relationship, that nothing stands alone. In this double fire, light multiplies, warmth deepens. Cling rightly, and you will illuminate.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The great Tao flows everywhere. It can go left or right. All things depend on it for life, and it does not turn away.' Hexagram 30 is the Tao's own clinging—not grasping, but flowing with all things. Fire clings to fuel, but does not own it. You cling to life, to love, to light, but if you try to own them, they die. The wise one clings as the Tao clings: depending, yet free; receiving, yet giving; burning, yet never consumed.

hexagrams.name: Influence (咸 - Xián)
hexagrams.heart: Lake over mountain. The mountain, solid and still, receives the lake's moisture. The lake, responsive and open, reflects the mountain's form. Influence is this mutual giving and receiving—not forced, not claimed, but natural as water seeking its own level. A young woman and a young man, drawn together without design. The lightest touch, the slightest glance—influence begins before words, before intention. It is the original connection, the source of all relationship.

ancient.rendering: Influence succeeds. Perseverance furthers. Taking a maiden brings good fortune.

hexagrams.judgment: Influence is the meeting of heaven and earth in human form. It succeeds because it is natural, not contrived. Perseverance in this natural openness furthers all relationships. Taking a maiden—entering into union with the receptive, the yielding—brings good fortune because it completes what was incomplete. Not through force, but through mutual attraction. The mountain does not seize the lake; it simply receives. The lake does not grasp the mountain; it simply reflects. This is the model for all true influence: to be fully yourself and let the other be fully themselves, and in that meeting, something new arises.
hexagrams.image: Lake over mountain. The noble one receives people with emptiness and thus encourages them. Lake over mountain: the water fills the hollows, reflecting whatever comes. The noble one learns: receive people with emptiness—not with preconceptions, not with judgments, but with the open space of genuine attention. In that emptiness, they are encouraged to be themselves. Influence is not about imposing; it is about creating the space for the other to appear.
lines: Influence in the toes. Toes are the smallest movement, the first stirring. Influence begins there, before you even know it. This is not yet action, just inclination. There is no blame, no praise—just the first hint of connection.

Influence in the calves. Misfortune. Staying brings good fortune. The calves move when the body moves. Influence here is still automatic, unthinking. If you follow it without awareness, misfortune comes. But if you stay—pause, reflect—good fortune follows. Do not let automatic influence carry you away.

Influence in the thighs. You are bound to what follows. To go forward brings humiliation. The thighs follow the hips, follow the whole body. Here, influence is stronger, but still passive. You are bound to what follows, swept along. If you go forward now, without clarifying, humiliation follows. Wait until you can act from the center, not the periphery.

Perseverance brings good fortune. Regret disappears. If you are unsettled, friends follow your thoughts. Now influence reaches the heart, the center. Perseverance here—staying true to what you feel—brings good fortune. Regret disappears because you are no longer passive; you are consciously engaged. Friends may follow your thoughts, drawn by your clarity, but you are not swayed. You are the one who sways.

Influence in the back of the neck. No regret. The neck connects head and body, thought and feeling. Influence here is complete, whole. No regret because you are fully present, fully responsive. The back of the neck cannot see what comes, yet it responds. This is trust: to respond without needing to see first.

Influence in the jaws, tongue, and cheeks. This is the outermost, the expression. Influence that reaches speech, that shapes words. Here, the inner becomes outer, the connection becomes communication. The line does not judge; it describes. What you say now carries all that came before.

trigrams.description: Mountain below, lake above. The mountain supports the lake; the lake reflects the mountain. Influence is this mutual resting and reflecting, the natural relationship of stillness and joy. The mountain does not need to be seen; it simply is. The lake does not need to hold; it simply reflects.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The valley spirit never dies; it is called the mysterious female. The gateway of the mysterious female is called the root of heaven and earth.' Hexagram 31 is the valley spirit, the mysterious female—the empty space that receives and thereby creates. Influence is not action; it is presence. Not doing; being. When you are fully present, empty of agenda, you become a valley. Others flow into you, and in that flowing, connection is born.

hexagrams.name: Duration (恒 - Héng)
hexagrams.heart: Thunder over wind. Thunder stirs, wind moves—both are constant, yet always changing. Duration is not rigidity; it is the faithfulness that underlies all transformation. The thunder returns with each storm; the wind blows where it will. Their patterns are reliable, their appearances unpredictable. Duration is the marriage of constancy and change, the vow that holds even as the partners grow.

ancient.chinese: 恒。亨，无咎，利貞，利有攸往。
ancient.rendering: Duration succeeds. No blame. Perseverance furthers. It furthers one to undertake something.

hexagrams.judgment: Duration is not staying the same; it is staying true. The thunder and wind do not repeat themselves exactly, but their nature endures. Success comes to those who find this deep constancy within change. No blame because you are not clinging to form; you are holding to essence. Perseverance in this deep holding furthers all things. Now it furthers to undertake something—because you are rooted, you can move without losing yourself. Duration is the root that allows the branches to sway.
hexagrams.image: Thunder and wind. The noble one stands firm and does not change direction. Thunder and wind together—movement upon movement. The noble one learns: stand firm in your direction, not in your position. Do not change your fundamental orientation, but be flexible in how you pursue it. The thunder does not stop being thunder; it just rolls differently each time. The wind does not stop being wind; it just blows where it will. So too, the noble one's virtue is constant, its expression varied.
lines: Seeking duration too hastily brings misfortune. Nothing that would further. To want duration now, to grasp at it, is to lose it. Duration cannot be seized; it can only be lived. Haste in this matter brings only misfortune.

Regret disappears. To seek duration too hastily brings regret, but if you can let that regret go, it disappears. The line offers a way: do not dwell on the mistake; simply return to the patient practice of constancy.

Not lasting in virtue brings shame. Perseverance in this brings danger. If you cannot hold to your own center, you will be shamed—by circumstance, by others, by yourself. And if you persevere in this unsteadiness, danger follows. Duration requires inner work.
No game in the field. You have sought duration in the wrong place, like hunting where there is no game. The field is empty because your aim was misplaced. Recognize this and redirect.

Lasting in virtue brings perseverance. Good fortune for a woman, misfortune for a man. This line reflects traditional roles: woman's constancy in the home brings good fortune; man's constancy in the world requires adaptation. But deeper: duration must be appropriate to context. What is constant in one sphere may be rigid in another. Know your place and last accordingly.

Restlessness as lasting brings danger. To be perpetually in motion, never settling, never deepening—this is not duration, but its opposite. If this restlessness becomes your lasting state, danger follows. Even the wind rests sometimes.

trigrams.description: Wind below, thunder above. Wind moves without ceasing; thunder stirs and rolls. Together, they show duration: not stillness, but reliable movement. The wind always blows; the thunder always comes. Their forms change; their nature endures.

hexagrams.taoist_reflection: The Tao Te Ching says: 'The softest thing in the world rides over the hardest thing in the world. That which has no substance enters where there is no space.' Hexagram 32 is the soft constancy that outlasts all hardness. Wind and thunder are soft—they cannot be grasped, yet they shape mountains and forests. Lasting virtue is the same: not rigid, but faithful; not unchanging, but true. In this soft constancy, all things are accomplished.
